image.altText: A composite image of the leaders of the Labor, Liberal and Greens parties.

items.synopsis: The independent tribunal that sets politician pay has determined to give federal MPs a 4 per cent pay rise, saying previous pay increases have been conservative.

title.children: PM's pay bumped to $586k, Dutton's to $417k as salary increases for federal politicians rolled out

image.altText: A tabby cat lies sleeping on a bookshelf with its head resting on a book.

items.synopsis: The RSPCA appeals for information over the "wicked, cowardly and callous" drowning of a beloved pet cat in the Swan River in Perth's east. WARNING: This article contains details that some readers may find distressing.

title.children: Tiger Tim's owners spent two weeks desperately searching for him, but he had been deliberately drowned in a river

image.altText: A composite image of John Marquis Hopkins and James Hayward.

items.synopsis: Convicted of child sex abuse, James Hayward is only the second MP in Western Australia's history, and the first in more than a century, to be removed from office for criminal activity. Here's what happens next.

title.children: Not since 1910 has WA’s parliament seen anything like the James Hayward scandal

image.altText: A woman in a sea of protesters holds a placard that reads "Not all men but too many"

items.synopsis: The women of the World Cup displayed nothing but merit. Extraordinary feats of skill. Flawless sportsmanship. Good behaviour on and off the pitch. They generated millions of new eyeballs for the beautiful game. And yet, they were overshadowed again and again by second-rate blokes, writes Annabel Crabb.

title.children: It's a classic tale of meritorious women overshadowed by second-rate blokes

image.altText: A worm in a specimen pot

items.synopsis: In a world first, doctors have extracted a living roundworm usually found in carpet pythons, from a patient's brain. They believe the infection occurred after the patient ate contaminated native greens.

title.children: 'Get it out of my hands right now': Surgeon removes living roundworm from patient's brain

image.altText: Woman holding baby with head turned away

items.synopsis: Essie Mitchell first spoke to her GP about a lump in her breast when she was 22. But it took 11 years and three more visits before her cancer was finally picked up, by which time it was too late to operate.

title.children: Mum's devastating diagnosis comes too late despite years of tests

image.altText: A woman holding a TEMU bag

items.synopsis: A flashy new online shopping app has been bombarding Australians on social media. While some see it as the saviour of China's economy, not everyone is convinced.

title.children: Are you getting a lot of ads for TEMU? The Chinese retailer is coming for Amazon – and it might win

image.altText: A woman with short brown hair wearing a black and red patterned blazer mid-sentence on a stage pointing her finger.

items.synopsis: Virgin Australia boss Jayne Hrdlicka has called on the federal government to rethink its decision to block Qatar Airways from increasing its flights to Australia, saying more flights would cut airfares by up to 40 per cent.

title.children: Virgin Australia boss says more Qatar Airways flights would lower airfares

image.altText: Custody photo of an Aboriginal man, staring directly into the camera.

items.synopsis: Earlier this month prosecutors downgraded a murder charge to manslaughter, prompting Warrick Walkerbear to plead guilty, foregoing the need for a Supreme Court trial.

title.children: Prison escapee to be sentenced in November for killing Kimberley woman

items.synopsis: Many of us are now dressed head to toe in plastic thanks to the invention of cheap and durable textiles like polyester. But the extent of the environmental impact from these garments might surprise you — we've tracked the life cycle of a polyester top from an oil field, through to when you chuck it in the bin.

title.children: In Australia, 6,000kg of clothing is dumped in landfill every 10 minutes. This is the life cycle of a polyester T-shirt

image.altText: Linda Burney, standing in front of a group of people, holds a press conference outside with gum trees behind her

items.synopsis: Australia's most senior Indigenous politician has broken her silence about her speech, having faced a campaign of whispers about her health.

title.children: 'My voice has changed': Linda Burney breaks silence amid whisper campaign

image.altText: Wildflower season comparison

items.synopsis: Tourists are beginning to arrive for the region's annual wildflower season, but locals warn this year's blooms may not meet expectations.

title.children: 'They can be very angry': Tourists disappointed by average wildflower season in WA's Midwest

image.altText: Margot winks at the camera as she claps in the air while wearing a gold glittery jumpsuit.

items.synopsis: Come on Barbie, lets go break some box office records in the US and internationally.

title.children: Barbie topples Harry Potter to become Warner Bros' highest-grossing film of all time

image.altText: picture of a man holding a metal bucket sitting in a football stadium behind the goal post

items.synopsis: Alex Agelopoulos, who injured a goalkeeper with a bucket when Melbourne Victory fans violently stormed AAMI Park, was released on bail after his lawyer immediately appealed the three-month jail term he was handed.

title.children: 'Bucket man' handed jail sentence over violent pitch invasion at Melbourne A-League game

image.altText: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen stands behind a lecturn cpvered in flowers. Two microphones are pointed at her.

items.synopsis: Taipei says it's hopeful to strengthen trade and bilateral relations despite Canberra's attempts to stabilise ties with Beijing.

title.children: Taiwan wants Australia's backing to join trade pact as Beijing pushes for it to be blocked

image.altText: A large set of drones is pictured inside a big warehouse-like space.

items.synopsis: There are five key observations which can be made about drones from their use in the war in Ukraine. And the Australian Defence Force needs to take notice, writes Mick Ryan.

title.children: A 44-day conflict was a sign of what was to come in Ukraine. Now we know drones are changing warfare

image.altText: Tails of Qantas and Virgin Australia aircraft

items.synopsis: Local stocks rise in afternoon trade and the bosses of Virgin and Qantas are at loggerheads on a decision to block extra flights by Qatar Airways. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX makes gains, Virgin calls for rethink on extra Qatar flights

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says customers should be able to claim or be refunded unredeemed flight credits. Qantas has set the end of the year as the deadline for when outstanding flight credits — totalling at least $470 million — need to be claimed. Of that amount, $370 million is owed to Australian Qantas customers, and $100 million is owed to Jetstar customers. Yesterday Qantas executives Alan Joyce, Steph Tully and Andrew McGiness could not say the value of flight credits owed to overseas customers, but it was less than $100 million. Qantas said its goal is to have "zero" flight credits remaining by December 31. Speaking in Perth, Mr Albanese said customers should be given a choice to get a refund or credit on products they buy, but don't use. "They [Qantas] need to look after their customers ... and there is no question that that needs to occur when people have made bookings in good faith," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says Qantas customers need to be given choice to claim flight credits or get a refund

children.content: says customers should be able to claim or be refunded

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The chief executive of Canberra Airport is calling for Qantas to be fined for its "appalling" flight cancellation rate. Fifty-three flights on its Canberra to Sydney route have been cancelled every month for the last six months — meaning Qantas has a cancellation rate of 11.5%. Qantas boss Alan Joyce yesterday told a Senate committee it was fairer to cancel more frequent Canberra to Sydney flights than regional flights that were less frequent. But Canberra Airport CEO Stephen Byron says that's not good enough. "When you have a cancellation rate of above 10%, which is just extraordinary and double any of the other routes, I think the federal government's got to have a look at fining Qantas because they're the only ones that do it ," he said. "If you fly Virgin to Sydney from Canberra, it's [the cancellation rate] about 3.6%, so Qantas cancel three times as often."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Canberra Airport boss says Qantas should be fined for 'appalling' flight cancellation rate

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) says steel manufacturer BlueScope Steel has been ordered to pay a $57.5 million penalty for attempting to fix prices for flat steel products supplied in Australia. The penalty ordered by the Federal Court today is the highest penalty ever imposed for cartel conduct in Australia. The Court also imposed a $575,000 penalty on BlueScope’s former general manager, Jason Ellis, which by Court order cannot be recovered from an insurance company. From the ACCC's press release: Justice O’Bryan said that “the conduct in the present case warrants a significant penalty to deter repetition by Mr Ellis and by others who may otherwise calculate that the rewards from such conduct outweigh the risks of detection. It is important that the deterrent effect of the penalty being imposed is not undermined by the ability of company directors and officers to insure against the financial cost of the penalty.” In December 2022 the Court found that BlueScope and Mr Ellis had attempted to induce eight steel distributors in Australia, and an overseas manufacturer, Yieh Phui, to enter agreements to fix and/or raise the level of pricing for flat steel products. “This should serve as a strong warning to all businesses and individuals that attempting to fix prices with competitors will have very serious consequences, even if the attempt fails and they do not reach an agreement,” ACCC Commissioner Liza Carver said. “We welcome this substantial penalty against BlueScope. It is important that penalties are sufficiently large to deter even large companies and their employees from breaching Australia’s competition laws.” “Cartel conduct is illegal because it cheats Australians by increasing the prices consumers and business customers have to pay, and by restricting healthy economic growth,” Ms Carver said. “If BlueScope had been successful in reaching an agreement to fix prices with its competitors, this would have reduced price competition and increased prices for flat steel products which are widely used in the construction, manufacturing, automotive and transport industries.” Justice O’Bryan found that the conduct by BlueScope was deliberate and systematic and considered that “only a substantial penalty for each of the attempts to induce cartel conduct will serve the objectives of specific and general deterrence”. He found that the conduct by BlueScope was of a serious kind, was carried out at a senior level of the company, had the potential to occasion significant loss and damage and to deliver substantial financial gain to BlueScope. BlueScope and Mr Ellis were also ordered to pay the ACCC’s costs.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Record $57.5 million penalty for BlueScope’s attempted price fixing

image.altText: A soldier wearing a camouflage taking a selfie from a low angle with the blue and yellow ukraine flag behind him on a rooftop

items.synopsis: The settlement on the front lines of the south-eastern front in the Zaporizhzhia region has been retaken from Russian forces, according to Ukraine Defence Ministry.

title.children: 'Blue and yellow flag will be raised': Ukraine liberates strategic settlement

image.altText: Artist Tank, wearing a black hoodie and dark beanie, stands in front of a wall mural.

items.synopsis: Tank, who recently spoke out about his designs being sold by the Chinese online retail giant, says Australians have "good standards" and "don't want to see anyone be ripped off for a fair day's work".

title.children: Artist known as Tank wins battle with Temu to get copycat art removed from sale

image.altText: An older man with dark hair and thick rimmed square glasses waring a suit and tie looks ahead in front of Qantas logos.

items.synopsis: Instead of being praised for Qantas's financial health, Alan Joyce is under fire — and it's all to do with how much taxpayer support it received versus how much tax it paid, writes business editor Ian Verrender.

title.children: As Alan Joyce prepares to take flight from Qantas, taxpayers are left to foot the bill

image.altText: A composite image shows the three marines in side-by-side images

items.synopsis: The pilot, crew chief and squadron executive officer have been identified as the three US marines killed in Sunday's Osprey crash on Melville Island in the Northern Territory.

title.children: US marines killed in Osprey crash on Tiwi Islands identified

image.altText: MJ O'Neill wears a top with spaghetti straps and smiles in a mid-cropped shot on the balcony with potplant behind her

items.synopsis: "My family's view was if it can help you, then do it. Because we want you to stay alive and we want you to be happy."

title.children: 'A lot of grief and anger to work through': Tips for telling your parents you have ADHD

image.altText: Osprey military aircraft taking off from landing helicopter assault vessel.

items.synopsis: The V-22 Osprey has recorded more than 50 fatalities in accidents over the past three decades. On Sunday, the aircraft's death toll grew again.

title.children: Dubbed 'the Widowmaker' after a series of deadly accidents, why is the Osprey still in use?

image.altText: Man in blue basketball uniform smiles and raises his hand in the air in victory celebration

items.synopsis: A catastrophic leg injury left Liam Hunt's doctors questioning whether he would walk again, let alone play basketball.

title.children: Liam was told he'd never play basketball again — he's now on his way to Europe to play professionally

image.altText: Two Australian batters and the team captain high-five at the end of a T20 match at the Commonwealth Games.

items.synopsis: A Senate inquiry examining why Victoria walked away from hosting the 2026 Commonwealth Games is holding hearings in the regional city of Bendigo.

title.children: Day 2 of the Commonwealth Games Senate inquiry — as it happened

image.altText: Jana Pittman on Q+A

items.synopsis: As politicians are forced to hear their bickering on the Voice is confusing, the Q+A panel agrees that there should be extra funds allocated for paid parental leave.

title.children: Jana Pittman labels Voice messaging 'confusing' on Q+A

image.altText: Cooking on a gas stove

items.synopsis: Experts say getting households and businesses that can easily disconnect from gas is key to meeting emission reduction targets.

title.children: New home gas bans will lead to energy source's 'death spiral', experts say

image.altText: A toddler in a blue onesie ith ears, wears socks, sits on an unmade bed with a velvet brown bedhead.

items.synopsis: Twenty-one-month-old Jordan Thompson died in a unit in a Singleton apartment block in March 2005. His mother's ex-boyfriend has pleaded not guilty to manslaughter.

title.children: Accused toddler killer talked about crushing up sedatives to make kids sleep, jury hears

image.altText: A Belgian cyclist sits up in the saddle and raises his fist in the air in celebration after crossing the finish line.

items.synopsis: Belgian cycling star and defending champion Remco Evenepoel is losing patience with La Vuelta's safety measures, as he crashes into the crowd seconds after winning stage three and is left bleeding heavily.

title.children: 'It's breaking my balls now': Remco Evenepoel left bloody from post-race crash in latest incident at chaotic La Vuelta

image.altText: Four men hold a giant dead alligator with its mouth open

items.synopsis: Four hunters in Mississippi have detailed their "mentally exhausting" seven-hour ordeal after they caught an alligator measuring more than four metres long.

title.children: Seven hour fight to nab 364kg record-breaking alligator in Mississippi river
